description.narrative: After several years in exile, DVB opened its first office in Yangon in 2012, when various reforms were initiated by the authorities and the government. DVB is a media organization with a mission to provide unbiased news to the people of Burma, but also highlights threat to the democracy of Myanmar. The Embassy in Bangkok and Sida look upon this support for 2014-15 as a phase-out.

Democratic Voice of Burma (DVB) har efter många år i exil nu flyttat sin verksamhet från Norge till Myanmar. Sedan tidigare har de också ett kontor i Chaing Main, Thailand. Beslutet att återvända till Myanmar kom efter de reformer som startade i landet under 2012, inte minst inom just medieområdet där förhandscensuren togs bort och en rad medielagar förändrades. Från kontoret i Chiang Mai görs huvuddelen av TV-sändingarna görs och DVB har inga planer på att flytta all verksamhet till Myanmar före de nationella valen 2015.
DVB är en medieorganisation med ett uppdrag att tillhandahålla opartiska nyheter till Myanmars befolkning i landet, såväl som till en internationell publik. De har dagliga sändningar via radio, TV och internet och har även sändingar på flera av landets många minoritetsspråk. DVB är en viktig oberoende nyhetskälla för människor i dagens Myanmar, där resten av mediemarknaden präglas av ojämlikhet och täta band mellan vissa ägare och regimen.
DVB står samtidigt för en utmaning eftersom flytten till Myanmar också innebär en förändring av deras egen organisation och uppdrag. De har påbörjat arbetet att bli en kommersiellt stark medieaktör som kan hävda sig i konkurrensen på Myanmars öppna marknad och generera reklamintänkter. Det är en stor omställning från en situation där DVB varit helt finansierad av givare under många år.
Medvetenheten om behovet av förändring är stor hos DVBs ledning och arbetet är i full gång. Ambassaden, i nära samarbete med Sida (ambassaden/Sida), har meddelat DVB att vi ser på detta stöd för 2014-15 som ett utfasningsstöd. Samtidigt är det viktigt att inse att många utmaningar återstår, både för DVB internt och externt. Till exempel gäller det huruvida reformerna i samhället fortskrider, hur regeringen beslutar dela ut TV licenser och hur myndigheterna agerar inför de nationella valen 2015.

sector.narrative: Media and free flow of information

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2015Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: In June 2015 DVB started broadcasting live TV and by that set a new standard in news reporting in Myanmar. With its hourly news updates (from 7 AM to 9 PM) DVB allowed the audience to follow on-going important events during the year, e.g the flooding that affected Myanmar during the summer and the national elections in November. Another new feature during the year was the production of series of investigative documentaries. The first series include the issues of problems of heath care, child labours, land grabbing and issues surrounding it, environment, human rights (disappearance of a Kachin women).
DVB has also continued to televise weekly debates on issues such as child soldiers, national identity and corruption. Debates broadcasted to the public are new in the Myanmar context, but have proved to be popular (over half a million views on Youtube). The format gradually intensified the number of programs about the elections. In 2015 15 special ‘DVB Election Debates’, with topics such as female participation, ethnic diversity and the impact of the flooding on the Elections, were aired. On November 4th this series reached its climax with the first ever ‘National Elections Debate’; the 6 main parties on the panel and over 300 guests (including a representative of the Section Office).
DVB also covered the election by means of a number of other productions, The Myanmar Institute for Democracy (MID), a non-profit organization dedicated to freedom of expression and the media monitored media coverage of the election. The findings confirms that DVB is the only independent Burmese run-media providing variety of views and diverse information. BBC radio (Myanmar) is another broadcaster which coverage is similar to that of the DVB. Coverage of all other broadcasters is unbalanced as they are pre-dominantly about President, Vice-Presidents and army. DVB coverage includes main opposition party National League for Democracy (NLD) and the then ruling party Union Solidarity and Development Party (USDP) most and second most respectively. DVB editorial policy makes sure that all contesting parties and candidates get fair share of DVB coverage in a balanced manner.
DVB has further been active in lobbying for equal conditions in the media market. Attempts have been made to influence the Broadcasting Law, which was eventually passed by the Parliament in August 2015. A few of DVB's inputs were taken into account, but the end result was far from ideal from DVB's point of view.
As DVB attempts to develop into a self-sustaining commercial company, management has embarked on a transformation of every aspect of the organization. If successful, the future organization will support a new business model and new revenue streams. This new model is driven primarily by Advertising Sales. In March 2015, sales management was put in place to begin transitioning DVB into a sales organization capable of competing in the Myanmar market. The effects have been immediate and the advertisement revenues quadrupled in 2015.
DVB has developed a new legal ownership structure that is suitable for the requirements of DVB business model, going from being funded by donor grants to becoming self-financing. Since DVB is being managed by mostly foreign citizens of Burma origin, it is quite complicated process to find a suitable structure. The plan is to set up a new company in Singapore, which will enter into a joint venture with DVB Multimedia as the local Myanmar partner. The new joint venture company will contain all non-journalism activities and may have directors and owners with foreign citizenship.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
